Continuous Improvement:
It is the expectation of the Mill to implement continuous improvement in its safety and environmental programs. Near-miss and safety incident investigations, root-cause analyses, and corrective action implementation support continuous improvement. Employees have been trained in conducting risk assessments to further evaluate jobsite and work procedure risks. Individual safety plans are developed for each employee at the Mill to define their role and commitment to safe work practices.

5 Year Accident History:
RMP regulations require the Mill to provide a five-year accident history for each regulated toxic substance. Based on 40 CFR 68.42(a), the five-year accident history covers only releases that have caused on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, or sheltering in place.

The Mill reported an accidental release of ClO2 on September 13, 2022 at approximately 8:00 a.m.  1,043 pounds of ClO2 were released from a process vessel over a 28-minute period. The release  was due to human error, with maintenance activity and process design failure as contributing factors. The release resulted in one employee injury, but did not result in property or environmental damage. As a result of the accident, equipment was upgraded and new process controls were implemented. If an accidental release should occur of this nature in the future, this section of the Risk Management Program will be updated.

Contractor employees must pass a written exam upon completion of the safety orientation to document proficiency with the presented material.

Emergency Planning and Response: 
The Mill has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. A formal review process to solicit employees’ input on Mill-wide procedures exists to improve emergency response plans. Employees and participants in both safety incidents and drills conduct critiques to obtain comments and observations, identify learnings, identify opportunities for performance improvement, and improve both emergency response planning and responder performance. Communication with team members and contractors occurs on formal and informal levels to ensure complete understanding of the required actions in the event of an emergency. The written plan, which is consistent with the approach in the National Response Team’s Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance (“One Plan”), contains:
•	Procedures for informing the surrounding public and local emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release from the Mill,
•	Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment of accidental human exposure,
•	Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release,
•	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment,
•	Procedures for reviewing and updating the plan, as necessary, and
•	Training for all employees in relevant procedures.

The Mill maintains emergency planning and response written procedures onsite.

Hot Work Permits (Safe Work Practices): 
The Mill has established a hot work permit program to control activities that may result in a fire or explosion in covered processes. Team members with appropriate and adequate skills and experience participate in the review of safe work practices through their involvement with safety sub-teams, the Mill safety core team, and ad-hoc task teams. A cross section of knowledgeable team members may be called upon to draft procedures and revisions to procedures. During the development of changes to critical activity procedures, emphasis is placed on involving a core functional team comprised of employees affected by the procedure. An issued permit will document that the fire prevention and protection requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252 have been implemented prior to the beginning of hot work operations. The permit will indicate the dates authorized for hot work and identify the equipment on which the hot work is to be performed. The permit will be kept on file until completion of hot work operations.

Contractors: 
The Mill has established a program to ensure that contractor activities  are performed in a safe manner. Team members at the Mill hold an integral role in interfacing with contractors working onsite. Team members often work side-by-side with contractor employees and have a high level of knowledge about how the work can affect, or be affected by, the process. Each team member and contractor employee is encouraged to communicate any questions or concerns about unsafe work activities or conditions. Incident Investigation: 
Under a Program 3 Prevention Program, the Mill is required to investigate any instance that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. A catastrophic release is defined as a release “that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment”.  

The Mill investigates all incidents that could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment to ensure that similar incidents can be prevented. Team members are involved in incident investigations to leverage their expertise in process operations and maintenance. Once investigation team reports are available, the results and recommendations of the team are provided to employees working in the process or operation. Communication, in the form of a report, is distributed to employees and is discussed in scheduled safety meetings and other ad hoc meetings with team members. The RMP Rule requires incident investigations and associated reports to include:
•	Date, time, and location of the incident,
•	Description of the incident,
•	The amount of release and duration of the incident,
•	Consequences of the incident,
•	Emergency response actions,
•	Factors contributing to the incident, and 
•	Root cause analysis.

The Mill will maintain summaries of any incident investigation and the resulting recommendations for corrective actions for five years and include the incident information in the five-year accident history of the RMP. Summaries will be made available for affected employees whose job tasks are relevant to the incident.

The Mill’s most recent incident investigation occurred on September 13, 2022.

Pre-startup Review: 
The Mill performs a safety review of a new or modified process prior to a process being placed into service to ensure that the process has been properly prepared for safe operation. The pre-startup review ensures that drawings have been updated, training has been completed, procedures have been written, and the necessary documentation has been prepared prior to the modification being put into service. Team members with appropriate knowledge and skills are employed in the development and implementation of the pre-startup review process. Team members are encouraged to ask safety questions, participate in pre-startup reviews, and communicate any identified concerns. 

The Mill’s most recent pre-startup review occurred on September 20, 2022.

Compliance Audits: 
In addition to regular safety and environmental compliance audits, the Mill conducts PSM and RMP compliance audits in accordance with OSHA PSM and EPA RMP requirements. In these audits, adherence to both IP corporate and Mill policies, internal procedures, and standards are verified. Team members are interviewed as part of audit protocols to permit them to provide input on the specific issues being audited. Audit reports, response plans, and status updates are shared with affected employees.   

The minimum requirements for the compliance audit include:
•	Performing an audit at least once every three years, 
•	Maintaining the last two audit reports,
•	The audit is conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process,
•	Documenting the appropriate response to each finding, and
•	Documenting any deficiencies identified and the corrective actions taken.

Mechanical Integrity: 
The Mill maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. Employees record equipment history, data and observations, maintain the SAP maintenance system database, and generate Reliability Maintenance System reports. Employees performing testing and inspection work is typically asked to review and provide comment on manufacturer recommendations for preventative maintenance procedures and testing frequency. Employees participate in equipment failure reviews and work process critiques, and are encouraged to make recommendations for change. Inspections and testing procedures shall follow good engineering practices and the frequency shall follow manufacturer recommendations, or more frequently, if necessary. If any deficiencies are identified, they will be corrected prior to further use of the equipment.

Management of Change: 
The Mill has an established management of change program to evaluate and approve all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process, to ensure that changes do not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be “a replacement in kind” are approved without completing the full management of change process. Changes other than “like kind” must be approved through the management of change process to ensure:
•	Potential accidents resulting from the change are prevented, 
•	Safety concerns of the changes are addressed,

Operating Procedures: 
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within covered processes, the Mill maintains written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting process activities. Mill engineers, operators, and management work together to develop the operating procedures defining how tasks related to process operations are safely performed. Mill employees participate in operating procedures development in several ways:
•	Employees are consulted during procedure development and implementation to determine if the procedures accurately reflect what is practiced in the field and what additional measures should be added to increase worker safety and protect the environment, 
•	Development of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) are assigned to employees that have recognized knowledge, experience, and job skills related to the assigned procedure, and
•	Implementation of new processes or procedures is assigned to a commissioning team to provide an opportunity for critique and scrutiny of work processes and procedures.
The Mill will ensure that the SOPs are updated whenever a major change occurs and prior to startup of any changed process

Employee Training: 
The Mill trains employees to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. Employees are trained through self-taught learning materials, including operation manuals, educational modules, and computer-based education programs. Additionally, employees are trained one-on-one through on-the-job training in the field. Employees are encouraged to identify educational needs and participate in educational development and implementation. Skills are demonstrated through written and oral examinations and through proficiency demonstrations.  The requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 allow the responsible official of a facility to certify that any employee involved in the process has been trained regarding process operations

The worst-case release of 17,572 pounds (lbs) of ClO2 can be characterized by evaluating the release under ambient conditions. The greatest distance for a regulated toxic substance from the worst-case scenario is determined based on chemical-specific substance properties, local characteristics near the Mill, meteorological conditions, and the duration of the release to inform the selection of the proper inputs to the DEGADIS model for identification of the greatest distance to toxic endpoint. For the worst-case scenario, the solution is assumed to be dense and the location is classified as rural, based on the limited presence of obstructions and variable terrain near the Mill. As the worst-case scenario is very unlikely, the OCA guidance also requires an alternative release scenario to be examined. The alternative release scenario is based on a more likely accidental release situation that would result in the toxic substance reaching an off-site endpoint.  

The distances to toxic endpoint for ClO2 from the Mill were determined using the U.S. EPA’s Dense Gas Dispersion Model (DEGADIS) and the OCA Guidance Reference Tables and Equations. DEGADIS simulates atmospheric dispersion of a ground-level dense gas, released into the atmospheric boundary layer over flat, level terrain. The methodology follows OCA guidance and uses the associated equations for releases of toxic liquids with passive mitigation.

Hazard Assessment, Worst Case Scenario:
The selected worst-case release scenario considers two 94,000-gallon storage tanks that are both  completely full prior to a release of their full quantities simultaneously. Although the Guidance allows for an evaluation of a single vessel, the possibility of a catastrophic event damaging the area in which the tanks will be maintained, and therefore causing a release of both tanks, must be considered. Each of the tanks are cylindrical, fully-insulated and unpressurized vessels, with a height of 40 feet and a diameter of 20 feet 6 inches. The tanks are located outdoors, approximately 4,000 feet from the Mill boundary.  The tanks will be placed in a secondary containment dike with surface area dimensions of 56 feet 2 inches by 27 feet 6 inches and a depth of 31 inches. A drain is present in the secondary containment area.

Process safeguards in use at the Mill include installation of process vents, manual and automatic shutoffs, and alarms. Mitigation systems in use at the Mill include dikes, berms, sumps, and drains.  Process area detectors are employed for monitoring of any hazardous releases.  

The ClO2 storage tanks are located outdoors within a secondary containment dike to mitigate any accidental release from the ClO2 storage tanks. The Mill maintains gas detectors inside the secondary containment that trigger an alarm in the event of an accidental release. Approximately 50 yards from the tanks is another gas detector adding an additional level of warning for faster mitigation of any accidental release.  The alarm sounds at one part per million (ppm).  The bleach plant control can close the connection between the tanks and a manual emergency stop is located approximately 100 yards to the west of the tanks

Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA):
An OCA investigates the potential adverse impacts of hazardous material release scenarios. The impacts and analysis results depend on the characteristics of the hazardous material, specifics of the facility layout and process operations, and the physical area surrounding the facility, such as the location of the nearby residential population and environmental receptors.  

The RMP regulations require the Mill to perform an OCA to determine the maximum distance to toxic endpoint for each regulated toxic substance in exceedance of its associated Threshold Quantity. For Program Level 3 processes, the OCA must evaluate the worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario for inclusion in the RMP.

Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Columbus Mill accident prevention program for chlorine dioxide complies with OSHA Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119).

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):
The Mill performs and periodically updates its PHA of the covered processes to identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process. The Mill encourages team members with knowledge and experience working with hazardous chemicals to participate in the PHA task team effort. The PHA findings are shared with employees with hazardous chemicals.  Employees are advised of any necessary changes brought about by the PHA and, in some cases, may be involved in the design change and implementation process. The previous Mill PHA was last updated on March 18, 2021.

International Paper Columbus Mill - RMP Executive Summary

The IP Columbus Mill is committed to operating in a manner that provides for the safety of its employees, the public, and for the protection of the environment. A key element of this commitment is the safe and proper handling of chemicals. Controls have been implemented to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances. In the event of an accidental release, mitigation steps are taken to stop, control, contain and clean up the releases.  

The Mill is located on approximately 3,000 acres of land in southern Lowndes County, Mississippi.  Approximately 350 employees work to keep the Mill safely operating at peak efficiency up to 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 52 weeks a year. The Mill uses two refrigerated storage tanks with a volume of 94,000 gallons each to hold a chlorine dioxide (ClO2) solution used to bleach kraft pulp. The ClO2 generator is capable of manufacturing approximately 600 gallons per minute at a concentration of 11.2 grams per liter (g/L). This substance is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.  Chlorine dioxide is the only RMP-covered substance used, manufactured, or stored on the Mill site in quantities above the designated Threshold Quantity.

The Mill has a primary goal of operating in 100% compliance with existing environmental regulations, which includes accurate and timely reporting and striving for steady reduction of environmental impacts. The Mill is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.

To protect the environment and the health and safety of employees and the public, the Mill expects full compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.
